company.name: TCS
company.description: Tata Consultancy Services is an IT services, consulting and business solutions organization that has been partnering with many of the world's largest businesses in their transformation journeys for over 50 years.

rounds.name: Aptitude Round
rounds.description: Comprehensive assessment covering numerical ability, logical reasoning, verbal comprehension, and analytical problem-solving capabilities.

rounds.name: Technical Round
rounds.description: In-depth technical evaluation covering programming fundamentals, data structures, algorithms, databases, operating systems, and computer networks.

rounds.name: Coding Round
rounds.description: Programming challenges testing algorithmic skills, code quality, optimization techniques, and practical problem-solving approach.

rounds.name: HR Round
rounds.description: Behavioral assessment evaluating communication skills, cultural fit, career motivation, and alignment with TCS values and work culture.

aptitude.question: A merchant has 1000 kg of sugar, part of which he sells at 8% profit and the rest at 18% profit. He gains 14% on the whole. How much sugar did he sell at 18% profit?
aptitude.explanation: Using alligation: (18-14):(14-8) = 4:6 = 2:3. So 18% profit part = 3/5 × 1000 = 600 kg.

aptitude.question: The ages of A and B are in the ratio 3:1. Fifteen years hence, the ratio will be 2:1. What is the present age of A?
aptitude.explanation: Let ages be 3x and x. (3x+15)/(x+15) = 2/1. 3x+15 = 2x+30. x = 15. A's age = 3×15 = 45 years.

aptitude.question: A person crosses a 600 m long street in 5 minutes. What is his speed in km/h?
The difference between simple interest and compound interest on a sum for 2 years at 8% per annum is Rs. 64. What is the sum?

A tank is filled by three pipes with uniform flow. The first two pipes operating simultaneously fill the tank in the same time during which the tank is filled by the third pipe alone. The second pipe fills the tank 5 hours faster than the first pipe and 4 hours slower than the third pipe. Find the time required by the first pipe to fill the tank.
aptitude.explanation: Let first pipe take x hours. Second takes (x-5) hours, third takes (x-9) hours. 1/x + 1/(x-5) = 1/(x-9). Solving: x = 15 hours.

aptitude.question: A shopkeeper buys 80 articles for Rs. 2,400 and sells them at a profit of 16%. What is the selling price of one article?
A sum of Rs. 1,550 was lent partly at 5% and partly at 8% per annum simple interest. The total interest received after 3 years was Rs. 300. How much was lent at 8%?
Two trains 140 m and 160 m long run at the speed of 60 km/h and 40 km/h respectively in opposite directions on parallel tracks. What is the time which they take to cross each other?
aptitude.explanation: Relative speed = 60 + 40 = 100 km/h = 100 × 5/18 = 27.78 m/s. Total distance = 140 + 160 = 300 m. Time = 300/27.78 = 10.8 seconds.

aptitude.question: The average of 11 results is 50. If the average of first 6 results is 49 and that of last 6 results is 52, what is the 6th result?
aptitude.explanation: Sum of 11 = 550. Sum of first 6 = 294. Sum of last 6 = 312. 6th result = 294 + 312 - 550 = 56.

aptitude.question: A person invests money in three different schemes for 6 years, 10 years and 12 years at 10%, 12% and 15% simple interest respectively. At the completion of each scheme, he gets the same interest. What is the ratio of his investments?
A alone can do a work in 15 days and B alone in 20 days. If they work on it together for 4 days, then what fraction of work is left?
If selling price is doubled, the profit triples. What is the profit percentage?
aptitude.explanation: Let CP = x, SP = y, Profit = y-x. New SP = 2y, New profit = 3(y-x). 2y-x = 3y-3x. 2x = y. Profit% = (y-x)/x × 100 = x/x × 100 = 100%.

aptitude.question: A sum of money placed at compound interest doubles itself in 4 years. In how many years will it amount to 8 times itself?
aptitude.explanation: If money doubles in 4 years, then in 8 years it becomes 4 times, and in 12 years it becomes 8 times.

aptitude.question: The ratio of the number of boys and girls in a college is 7:8. If the percentage increase in the number of boys and girls be 20% and 10% respectively, what will be the new ratio?
A man buys a scooter for Rs. 1,400 and sells it at a loss of 15%. What is the selling price of the scooter?

A sum of Rs. 2,665 is lent into two parts so that the interest on the first part for 8 years at 3% per annum may be equal to the interest on the second part for 3 years at 5% per annum. Find the second sum.
The population of a town increased from 1,75,000 to 2,62,500 in a decade. What is the average percent increase per year?
aptitude.explanation: Total increase = 87,500. Percentage increase = (87500/175000) × 100 = 50%. Average per year = 50/10 = 5%.

aptitude.question: The average weight of A, B and C is 45 kg. If the average weight of A and B is 40 kg and that of B and C is 43 kg, what is the weight of B?
aptitude.explanation: A+B+C = 135. A+B = 80. B+C = 86. Adding last two: A+2B+C = 166. B = 166-135 = 31 kg.

aptitude.question: A tank has a leak which would empty it in 8 hours. A tap is turned on which admits 3 liters per minute into the tank and it is now emptied in 12 hours. What is the capacity of the tank?
aptitude.explanation: Let capacity = C. Leak empties C in 8 hrs, so rate = C/8 per hour. Inflow = 3×60 = 180 liters/hour. Net rate = 180 - C/8. Tank empties in 12 hrs: (180 - C/8) × 12 = -C. 2160 - 1.5C = -C. C = 4320. Wait, recalculating: Net outflow = C/12. C/12 = C/8 - 180. C/12 - C/8 = -180. -C/24 = -180. C = 4320. But with inflow it takes 12 hours to empty, so C/8 - 180 = C/12. 3C/24 - 180 = 2C/24. C/24 = 180. C = 4320. Hmm, marked answer is 8640.

aptitude.question: A man takes twice as long to row a distance against the stream as to row the same distance in favour of the stream. If the speed of the stream is 3 km/h, what is the speed of the man in still water?
aptitude.explanation: Let man's speed = x. Downstream speed = x+3, Upstream = x-3. Time ratio = 2:1, so speed ratio = 1:2. (x-3):(x+3) = 1:2. 2(x-3) = x+3. 2x-6 = x+3. x = 9 km/h.

technical.question: What is the difference between stack and queue?
options: Stack is FIFO, Queue is LIFO
Stack is LIFO, Queue is FIFO
technical.explanation: Stack follows LIFO (Last In First Out) principle, while Queue follows FIFO (First In First Out) principle.

technical.question: What is the time complexity of inserting a node at the end of a singly linked list?
technical.explanation: Inserting at the end requires traversing the entire list to find the last node, making it O(n). With a tail pointer, it becomes O(1).

technical.question: Which data structure is used in breadth-first search (BFS)?
technical.explanation: BFS uses a queue to store nodes at each level and process them in FIFO order.

technical.question: What is inheritance in object-oriented programming?
technical.explanation: Inheritance allows a class to inherit properties and methods from a parent class, promoting code reusability.

technical.question: In SQL, which command is used to retrieve data from a database?
technical.explanation: SELECT command is used to query and retrieve data from database tables.

technical.question: What is a primary key in a database?
options: A key that can be null
A key that uniquely identifies each record
technical.explanation: A primary key is a column or set of columns that uniquely identifies each row in a table and cannot contain NULL values.

technical.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of linear search?
technical.explanation: Linear search checks each element sequentially, so in the worst case (element not found or at end), it takes O(n) time.

technical.question: What is method overloading?
technical.explanation: Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters (number, type, or order).

technical.question: Which searching algorithm requires the array to be sorted?
technical.explanation: Binary Search and Jump Search both require the array to be sorted to work correctly.

technical.question: What is a deadlock in operating systems?
technical.explanation: Deadlock occurs when two or more processes are waiting indefinitely for resources held by each other, creating a circular wait.

technical.question: In a binary tree, what is a leaf node?
technical.explanation: A leaf node is a node that has no children (both left and right pointers are null).

technical.question: What is normalization in databases?
technical.explanation: Normalization is the process of organizing data to minimize redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller, related tables.

technical.question: Which protocol is used for sending emails?
technical.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending emails across networks.

technical.question: What is the difference between abstract class and interface?
options: Abstract class can have concrete methods, interface cannot (pre-Java 8)
technical.explanation: Abstract classes can have concrete methods and constructors. Interfaces (before Java 8) could only have abstract methods.

technical.question: What is the purpose of a constructor?
technical.explanation: A constructor is a special method called when an object is created to initialize its state and allocate resources.

technical.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in a hash table (average case)?
technical.explanation: Hash tables provide O(1) average-case access time through direct key-to-index mapping using hash functions.

technical.question: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
options: TCP is connection-oriented, UDP is connectionless
technical.explanation: TCP is connection-oriented and guarantees reliable delivery. UDP is connectionless and doesn't guarantee delivery but is faster.

technical.question: What is a foreign key?
technical.explanation: A foreign key is a column or set of columns that establishes a link between data in two tables by referencing the primary key of another table.

technical.question: Which sorting algorithm has the best average-case time complexity?
technical.explanation: Merge Sort has O(n log n) average and worst-case time complexity, making it efficient for large datasets.

technical.question: What is an operating system?
options: System software managing hardware and software
technical.explanation: An operating system is system software that manages computer hardware, software resources, and provides services for computer programs.

coding.question: Check if a number is prime
coding.description:
Given a positive integer n, return true if it is a prime number, otherwise return false. A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.

Example:
Input: n = 7
Output: true

Input: n = 12
Output: false

coding.question: Find the sum of digits of a number
coding.description:
Given an integer n, return the sum of its digits.

Example:
Input: n = 1234
Output: 10
Explanation: 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 = 10

Input: n = 567
Output: 18
coding.codeSnippet:
def sumOfDigits(n):
    n = abs(n)  # Handle negative numbers
    total = 0
    
    while n > 0:
        total += n % 10
        n //= 10
    
    return total

# Alternative: return sum(int(d) for d in str(abs(n)))

# Time: O(log n), Space: O(1)

coding.question: Reverse an integer
coding.description:
Given a signed 32-bit integer x, return x with its digits reversed. If reversing x causes the value to go outside the signed 32-bit integer range [-2³¹, 2³¹ - 1], then return 0.

Example:
Input: x = 123
Output: 321

Input: x = -123
Output: -321

Input: x = 120
Output: 21
coding.codeSnippet:
def reverse(x):
    sign = -1 if x < 0 else 1
    x = abs(x)
    
    reversed_num = 0
    while x > 0:
        reversed_num = reversed_num * 10 + x % 10
        x //= 10
    
    reversed_num *= sign
    
    # Check 32-bit overflow
    if reversed_num < -2**31 or reversed_num > 2**31 - 1:
        return 0
    
    return reversed_num

# Time: O(log n), Space: O(1)

coding.question: Find GCD (Greatest Common Divisor) of two numbers
coding.description:
Given two integers a and b, return their greatest common divisor.

Example:
Input: a = 12, b = 18
Output: 6

Input: a = 17, b = 13
Output: 1
coding.codeSnippet:
def gcd(a, b):
    # Euclidean algorithm
    while b:
        a, b = b, a % b
    return a

# Recursive approach:
# def gcd(a, b):
#     if b == 0:
#         return a
#     return gcd(b, a % b)

# Time: O(log(min(a, b))), Space: O(1) iterative

coding.question: Find LCM (Least Common Multiple) of two numbers
coding.description:
Given two integers a and b, return their least common multiple.

Example:
Input: a = 4, b = 6
Output: 12

Input: a = 15, b = 20
Output: 60

coding.question: Check if a number is Armstrong number
coding.description:
An Armstrong number (also known as narcissistic number) is a number that is equal to the sum of its own digits each raised to the power of the number of digits.

Example:
Input: n = 153
Output: true
Explanation: 1³ + 5³ + 3³ = 1 + 125 + 27 = 153

Input: n = 123
Output: false
coding.codeSnippet:
def isArmstrong(n):
    digits = str(n)
    num_digits = len(digits)
    total = sum(int(d) ** num_digits for d in digits)
    return total == n

# Alternative without string conversion:
# def isArmstrong(n):
#     original = n
#     num_digits = len(str(n))
#     total = 0
#     while n > 0:
#         digit = n % 10
#         total += digit ** num_digits
#         n //= 10
#     return total == original

# Time: O(d) where d is number of digits, Space: O(1)

coding.question: Generate Fibonacci sequence up to n terms
coding.description:
Given an integer n, return the first n numbers in the Fibonacci sequence. The Fibonacci sequence starts with 0 and 1, and each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two.

Example:
Input: n = 7
Output: [0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8]

Input: n = 5
Output: [0, 1, 1, 2, 3]

coding.question: Count vowels in a string
coding.description:
Given a string s, count the number of vowels (a, e, i, o, u) in it. Case insensitive.

Example:
Input: s = 'Hello World'
Output: 3
Explanation: e, o, o

Input: s = 'Programming'
Output: 3

coding.question: Find all prime numbers up to n (Sieve of Eratosthenes)
coding.description:
Given an integer n, return all prime numbers less than or equal to n.

Example:
Input: n = 10
Output: [2, 3, 5, 7]

Input: n = 20
Output: [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19]

coding.question: Remove duplicate elements from array (unsorted)
coding.description:
Given an integer array nums, remove duplicates and return the array with unique elements. Order doesn't matter.

Example:
Input: nums = [1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5]
Output: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Input: nums = [5, 5, 5, 1, 2, 2]
Output: [5, 1, 2]
coding.codeSnippet:
def removeDuplicates(nums):
    return list(set(nums))

# If order needs to be preserved:
# def removeDuplicates(nums):
#     seen = set()
#     result = []
#     for num in nums:
#         if num not in seen:
#             result.append(num)
#             seen.add(num)
#     return result

# Time: O(n), Space: O(n)
# Hash set approach

coding.question: Find the nth Fibonacci number
coding.description:
Given an integer n, return the nth Fibonacci number (0-indexed).

Example:
Input: n = 6
Output: 8
Explanation: F(6) = 8 in sequence [0,1,1,2,3,5,8]

Input: n = 10
Output: 55
coding.codeSnippet:
def fibonacci(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return n
    
    prev2, prev1 = 0, 1
    
    for i in range(2, n + 1):
        current = prev1 + prev2
        prev2 = prev1
        prev1 = current
    
    return prev1

# Recursive (less efficient):
# def fibonacci(n):
#     if n <= 1:
#         return n
#     return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)

# Time: O(n), Space: O(1) iterative

coding.question: Find power of a number (x^n)
coding.description:
Given two integers x and n, calculate x raised to the power n.

Example:
Input: x = 2, n = 10
Output: 1024

Input: x = 3, n = 4
Output: 81
coding.codeSnippet:
def power(x, n):
    # Handle negative power
    if n < 0:
        x = 1 / x
        n = -n
    
    result = 1
    current_product = x
    
    while n > 0:
        if n % 2 == 1:
            result *= current_product
        current_product *= current_product
        n //= 2
    
    return result

# Simple approach: return x ** n

# Time: O(log n), Space: O(1)
# Binary exponentiation

coding.question: Sort an array using bubble sort
coding.description:
Given an integer array nums, sort it in ascending order using bubble sort algorithm.

Example:
Input: nums = [64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90]
Output: [11, 12, 22, 25, 34, 64, 90]

Input: nums = [5, 1, 4, 2, 8]
Output: [1, 2, 4, 5, 8]

coding.question: Find the transpose of a matrix
coding.description:
Given a matrix, return its transpose. The transpose of a matrix is obtained by flipping rows and columns.

Example:
Input: matrix = [[1,2,3],[4,5,6],[7,8,9]]
Output: [[1,4,7],[2,5,8],[3,6,9]]

Input: matrix = [[1,2],[3,4]]
Output: [[1,3],[2,4]]
coding.codeSnippet:
def transpose(matrix):
    rows = len(matrix)
    cols = len(matrix[0])
    
    result = [[0] * rows for _ in range(cols)]
    
    for i in range(rows):
        for j in range(cols):
            result[j][i] = matrix[i][j]
    
    return result

# Alternative using zip:
# def transpose(matrix):
#     return list(map(list, zip(*matrix)))

# Time: O(m × n), Space: O(m × n)

coding.question: Check if two strings are anagrams
coding.description:
Two strings are anagrams if they contain the same characters in the same frequencies, but possibly in different orders.

Example:
Input: s1 = 'listen', s2 = 'silent'
Output: true

Input: s1 = 'hello', s2 = 'world'
Output: false
coding.codeSnippet:
def isAnagram(s1, s2):
    # Quick check: different lengths can't be anagrams
    if len(s1) != len(s2):
        return False
    
    return sorted(s1) == sorted(s2)

# Alternative using Counter:
# from collections import Counter
# def isAnagram(s1, s2):
#     return Counter(s1) == Counter(s2)

# Time: O(n log n), Space: O(1)
# Sorting approach

Hr.question: Tell me about yourself.
Hr.answer: I am a highly motivated computer science graduate with a strong foundation in programming, data structures, and algorithms. My academic journey has equipped me with both technical skills and problem-solving abilities. I have worked on several projects that demonstrate my ability to apply theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios. I am particularly drawn to TCS because of its reputation as a pioneer in the IT services industry and its commitment to innovation and employee development.

Hr.question: Why TCS?
Hr.answer: TCS is a global leader with over 50 years of excellence in the IT industry. I am impressed by TCS's focus on digital transformation, its diverse project portfolio across industries, and the strong learning culture fostered through programs like TCS iON. The opportunity to work with world-class clients and contribute to impactful solutions while growing my career in such a reputed organization is what attracts me to TCS.

Hr.question: What are your strengths?
Hr.answer: My key strengths include strong analytical thinking, quick learning ability, and excellent teamwork skills. I am detail-oriented and always strive for quality in my work. I adapt well to new technologies and environments, and I have demonstrated consistent performance under pressure during my academic projects and internships.

Hr.question: What is your greatest weakness?
Hr.answer: I tend to be overly critical of my own work, which sometimes causes me to spend extra time perfecting tasks. However, I have been working on this by setting realistic deadlines, prioritizing effectively, and learning to balance quality with timely delivery. This has helped me become more efficient while maintaining high standards.

Hr.question: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
Hr.answer: In five years, I see myself as an experienced professional at TCS, having successfully contributed to multiple projects and gained expertise in specific technology domains. I aspire to take on greater responsibilities, possibly in a technical leadership role, and mentor junior colleagues. I want to continue learning and growing with TCS while making meaningful contributions to client success.

Hr.question: Tell me about a challenging project you worked on.
Hr.answer: During my final year, I worked on a machine learning project to predict student performance. We faced challenges with data quality and model accuracy. I took the initiative to research advanced preprocessing techniques, implemented feature engineering, and experimented with multiple algorithms. Through persistent effort and team collaboration, we improved our model's accuracy by 15% and delivered a successful presentation. This taught me the value of perseverance, research, and teamwork.

Hr.question: Why should we hire you?
Hr.answer: You should hire me because I bring a strong technical foundation, eagerness to learn, and dedication to excellence. I am not just looking for a job but a career where I can contribute and grow. My problem-solving skills, adaptability, and positive attitude make me confident that I will quickly integrate into TCS's culture and add value to your projects and teams.

Hr.question: Are you willing to relocate and work in shifts?
Hr.answer: Yes, absolutely. I understand that working in the IT industry, especially with global clients, requires flexibility. I am fully prepared to relocate to any location and work in any shift as required by the project. My priority is to contribute effectively to the team and ensure client satisfaction.

Hr.question: Describe your teamwork experience.
Hr.answer: In my software engineering course project, I worked with a team of four to develop a web application. I took responsibility for backend development and database design. When we encountered integration issues, I facilitated discussions to identify the root cause and worked collaboratively to resolve them. I ensured clear communication through regular meetings and documentation. The project was completed successfully and received excellent feedback, reinforcing my belief in the power of effective teamwork.

Hr.question: Do you have any questions for us?
Hr.answer: Yes, I would like to know more about the initial training program for new joiners at TCS and how the company supports continuous skill development. Also, could you share insights about the typical career progression path and the kinds of projects that freshers typically work on initially?
